title: Which party will control the US Senate after the November 2016 election?
preds: I think the FBI emails revelation from October 28th did more damage to down-ticket Democrats than it did to Secretary Clinton.  My sense is that voters were already inclined to ticket split this year given how unpopular the Presidential nominees are, and that just reminded them of how much they distrust politicians in general, and Secretary Clinton in particular.  Democrats COULD pull it out, but I'm giving Republicans a slight advantage here.
My odds are that the Republicans will be getting 52+ Senate seats. 🤔👏🏻
538 gives it basically a coin flip now.
I do not consider myself better at predictions than Nate Silver (538) :(

http://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2016/11/election-2016-nevada-harry-reid-clinton-trump-early-vote-latinos-214426 It seems to me that we have slightly moved beyond polls at this point.  What I mean is that polls (i.e., 538 and Upshot) measure intent.  Who is in who's tent, and who intends to vote.  What we want to know is who is doing what - again, what the ground game is, who is early voting.  This article gives one peak in the window of the Democrat's get out the vote efforts in Nevada.   Note that I worry I am moving from facts and numbers to innuendo and anecdotal evidence.  I have read that early voting does indicate trends, and I have read the reverse.  An example is Trump saying his rallies are huge and have huge energy.  That doesn't tell me how a state will vote.  But, I believe that this article does tell us something important about Nevada. OK, here's my final forecast. Democrats will pick up Illinois, Nevada, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin, and either Missouri, New Hampshire or North Carolina.  D's will be 51, R's will be 49. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Senate_elections,_2016
http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-election-forecast/senate/ This is important, since the Virginia seat being left by Kaine will likely be filled by the Democratic governor and be a Democrat.  But, there will be a special election the following year.  Then, the seat naturally comes up on the 6 year cycle in 2 years - thus another election.  Lots of opportunity for folks to get pissed at Washington, and vote out the incumbent.  Incumbents have a huge advantage, but the next few years in Virginia are going to be wild.  And the Senate could flip a few times based upon it.    https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2016/11/01/why-the-battle-for-control-of-the-senate-could-stretch-into-2017/

Nevada and New Hampshire look to better than tossups for the Democrats right now, Pennsylvania still looks like a tossup, and Missouri looks like a close race now, though probably still better than a tossup for the Republicans. I calculate my number using a Poisson Binomial Distribution[1] for the 15 closest races, using an average probability for each race from several forecasts[2], and adjusting where I think the probabilities might be a bit off.  I assume that the Democrats have a 95% chance of holding the VP, in which case 50 seats is enough for a majority.  This method has the implicit assumption that the races are completely independent of each other which isn't totally true, but I do think that senate races are close enough to being independent. [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Poisson_binomial_distribution
[2] http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2016/upshot/senate-election-forecast.html

On the morning of 9 November, the Ds will either have won enough seats to have a clean majority in January or there will be a tie at 50, which VP Kaine will break.  That, however, is not what the question asks, for at least three reasons:   On the morning of 9 November, "after the November 2016 election," no matter the election result, the Rs will still "control the US Senate" for several more weeks; or just enough D Senators or Senators-elect could die (or resign, or be beamed up to the mothership) in November or December that the Rs would still control the Senate in January; or the Louisiana runoff in December could decide the issue.   I continue to predict as if the question were along the lines of "Which party will control the US Senate when the new Congress convenes?" which allows for both the death and Louisiana scenarios above; or "As a result of the 2016 elections, which party will have won a majority of votes [not seats, on account of the VP's tie-breaking power] in the US Senate for the term beginning in January 2017?"  which allows for Louisiana but disregards the death scenario.   Presumably those who wrote this question meant to ask about the election result, including Louisiana, but that's not what the Q says (assuming charitably that it's not meant to be a trick question hinging on the interval between November and January).   One grows tired of This Sort Of Thing, which is all over this site like a rash.  Asking us to make falsifiable predictions requires the GJedi to come up with unambiguous formulations.  Not happening.

-The majority of seats up for election (24 out of 34) are held by Republican incumbents, many of whom are freshmen who were swept into office in the Republican wave of 2010. 
- The Senate election coincides with a presidential election, which should be a boon to Democratic candidates (given Hillary's present lead). Democrats have made gains in the Senate in the last two presidential elections, while they have suffered losses in the years between. 
- Confirmation of a new Supreme Court justice requires 60 votes in the Senate which makes taking control of the chamber even more pivotal this year.  Assuming that the Senate continues to block any nominee of President Obama, confirmation will be left to the newly elected Senate in 2017. This puts increased pressure on both parties to win the Senate in 2016, as the chamber will have the ability to confirm or deny the next president's nominees. ***Today's NEW YORK TIMES' UPSHOT says Democrats now have a 60% chance of winning the US Senate (based on their state and national polls).  The UpShot is using a model that calculates winning probabilities for each Senate race.  They also use 150 different state polls and info on the candidates' political experience, fundraising, and the state's past election results.  They do, however, say that with some many races still up for grabs, the most likely scenario right now is a tie. ***FIVETHIRTYEIGHT notes that Trump is dragging down Senate races as there has been "an increasingly strong relationship between how a state votes for president and how it votes for Senate over the past few election cycles. The D's need to net 4 seats to control the Senate, if they also when the White House, otherwise they need to win 5. Of the 10 D-held Senate seats up for election, only Reid (NV) is currently a toss up, with Bennet (CO) slightly less than a certainty as well. So the D's have a lower bound of -2 seats. Of the 24 R-held seats, 7 are currently toss ups: Rubio (FL), Kirk (IL), IN (Coats), Ayotte (NH), Portman (OH), Toomey (PA), Johnson (WI). McCain (AZ), Blunt (MO), and Burr (NC) are weak favorites, and Murkowski (AK), Isakson (GA), and Grassley (IA) are strong favorites. Therefore, D's have an upper bound of +13[1] Assuming that the elections (including the presidential election) are independent (which they're not, of course), the D's expected gain is 5.57 Senate seats! It also gives the D's a 65% chance of taking 4 or more seats, and 56% chance of taking more than 5. If we think that the D's also have a (let's just say) 75% of keeping the White House, then the probability that they will take back the Senate is 0.56 + (0.09*.75) = 0.6275, which I'll round down to 62%. That's a lot higher than I thought a few days ago[2]! Math error maybe? Can't see it at the moment, but I'll return to this later when I have a clearer head and see if I can spot one. -- [1] http://cookpolitical.com/senate/charts/race-ratings
[2] http://cookpolitical.com/about/accuracy

Short summary: one or two of eleven races have democrats comfortably ahead, the rest have republicans ahead but not by much. Democrats have 45 seats + 2 seats, so need to only win 2 of 9 close races (if Hillary wins, ortherwise they need 3). This seems likely.  Let's see if we can break this down to make the above argument a little more rigorous:  - Of the seats that are up for grabs, there are 11 with a reasonable probability of going either way. 
- Before analyzing these 11, the D's have 45 seats and the R's have 44. 
Of the remaining eleven:  - Nevada looks pretty close to tied (As of now I give a 48% chance Dems win) 
- Arizona looks like it'll go Republican: John McCain's name recognition/incumbency coupled with some not so new polls (Dems 20%)
- Missouri looks like it'll go Republican though it'll be closer than one would expect (Dems 35%)
- Illinois will likely go Blue (though there was no polling I could find, so I'm basing on Illinois leaning blue) -- Dems (70%)
- Indiana (will Evan Bayh make it close?) -- (Dems 40%) 
- Ohio (looks like R's have a slight edge) -- (Dems 45%)
- Pennsylvania (looks like R's have a slight edge) -- (Dems 45%)
- Florida (Rubio's polling ahead) -- (Dems 35%)
- New Hampshire (Slight R lead so far ) -- (Dems 45%)
- North Carolina -- (Dems 50%)
- Wisconsin looks like it'll go Blue (Dems 90%) - Admittedly, my estimates are rough and possibly pessimistic if you're a Democrat, considering they are coming on the heals of a bad polling week for Dems. Nevertheless, the numbers are the numbers.  - Running a computer simulation with these odds gives the democrats at least 4 seats about 85% (Relevant if Hillary wins, which I'm giving 70%) of the time and at least 5 seats about 66% of the time (Relevant if Trump wins -- 30%).  - Final estimate: 0.85*0.7 + 0.66*0.3 = approximately 0.81 References:

Over the holiday weekend, the threat advanced on two fronts. First, the Libertarian Convention in Orlando, which nominated a relatively experienced ticket of two former Republican governors: Gary Johnson of New Mexico and Bill Weld of Massachusetts as his running mate. Second, Weekly Standard editor and "Never Trump" activist Bill Kristol hinted on Twitter that his efforts to draft a third party conservative candidate to rival Trump may have finally bore fruit. The payoff turned out to be a less than well-known name, however, in David French, a decorated Iraq veteran and staff writer at National Review. A third party would give conservatives ideologically opposed to Trump a megaphone to carry on their message in exile. There's also a strategic argument: Never Trump leaders assume the presumptive GOP nominee is on track for a devastating defeat and worry that disgruntled conservatives won't show up to the polls to support Republican candidates down ballot. Democrats have a strong chance of winning back the Senate thanks to a favorable map, and many of the most important races are in swing states including Florida, Ohio, Pennsylvania and New Hampshire. The House is a much tougher climb, but not impossible in a blowout situation. Republicans have made tremendous gains at the state level under President Obama, and there are concerns Trump could reverse their progress there as well.

I think it is unlikely that HRC would choose Sen. COMMENT:  This shifting in RNC fundraising and campaign support from the presidential race to the Senate (& House) races suggests several things to me:
1)  the difficulty the RNC is having with fundraising bodes ill, I'd think, for the success of the Trump campaign
2)  the RNC's decision to shift fundraising and spending to Senate (& House) races suggests to me a concern that GOP control of the  Senate could be lost and a belief that it could be retained if adequate resources were devoted to the effort to do so. I don't recall a party ever before severing its support for its presidential candidate from support for down-ticket races.  Usually, the thinking is that "a rising tide raises all boats" and that they way to bring the tide in is to win the presidency.   This is a very interesting situation:  dual fundraising efforts--presidential and congressional, with a greater emphasis on the down-ticket races.  In general, I think the RNC's decision to shift fundraising to Senate races is very clear-eyed, rational and wise.  I'm lowering my forecast for a Democrat take over of the Senate, from 80% to 66.

I started with Wikipedia's list of competitive seats and tally of recent predictions (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Senate_elections,_2016).  I then eliminated any seat which was voted safe in three of the last four predictions, which left me with 43 Democratic senators, 43 Republican senators and a list of 13 seats plausibly in play. Let's go through them one at a time. Arizona - John McCain (R) incumbent but facing a primary challenge. This is rated leans or likely Republican by all four projections, though current polling show a competitive race in favour of the Republicans. 
Colorado - Michael Bennet (D) incumbent. This race is unanimously rated as leaning Democrat. 
Florida - Marco Rubio (R) isn't running. Unanimously rated as a toss-up. Polling shows a competitive race in favour of the Democrats. 
Illinois - Mark Kirk (R) incumbent. Rated as a toss-up by two outlets, slightly Democrat by two others. Polling shows a competitive race in favour of the Democrats. 
Indiana - Dan Coats (R) isn't running. Unanimously rated likely Republican. 
Iowa - Chuck Grassley (R) incumbent. Rated safe Republican by two outlets, likely Republican by two others, with what polling there is showing a strong Republican lead. 
Missouri - Roy Blunt (R) incumbent. Unanimously rated likely Republican. 
Nevada - Harry Reid (D) isn't running. Unanimously rated a toss-up. 
New Hampshire - Kelly Ayotte (R) incumbent, but also a potential VP pick. Rated a toss-up by three of four outlets, slightly Republican by the fourth. Polling shows a competitive race with a Republican edge. 
North Carolina - Richard Burr (R) incumbent. Rated lean or likely Republican by all four outlets. Polling shows a competitive race with a Republican lead.
Ohio - Rob Portman (R) incumbent. Rated a tossup by one outlet, a lean Republican by three others. Polling shows a competitive race with a Democrat edge.
Pennsylvania - Pat Toomey (R) incumbent. Rated a tossup by one outlet, a lean Republican by three others. Polling shows a Republican lead. 
Wisconsin - Ron Johnson (R) incumbent. Rated a tossup by tow outlets, a lean Democrat by two others. Polling shows a Democrat lead.  This really does look too close to call at this stage, particularly with so many primaries still undecided. Having said that, the decisive factor for me at this point is the Republican primary race, which will certainly have down-ballot effects. Donald trump's negative favourability ratings have been well-publicized, but Ted Cruz also has a -19 spread according to the latest RCP average (http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/other/cruz_favorableunfavorable-3887.html). That's five points worse than Clinton, despite the fact that Clinton is far better known and (in my view) that has shielded Cruz somewhat from how far from centre his voting record is.  In either case, Democratic get out the vote efforts seem likely to be more effective than their Republican equivalents, which could be decisive in any number of close Senate races.

Republicans need to have a winning percentage of 0.64 (not 0.65 as I had thought) or higher in the 17 competitive races in order to end up with 51 or more seats in the senate. According to the 4-source model I used last time, the probability of that happening is 0.44. In contrast, Democrats need to have a winning percentage of 0.46 (rather than 0.47) or higher in the 17 competitive races in order to end up with 51 or more seats in the senate. That leaves a probability of 0.30 that Democrats and Republicans will have an equal number of Senate seats as the 2017 legislative season beings. Fun!  Since I currently think that neither Republicans nor Democrats have a clear leg up in the presidential race (or, more accurately, I believe that it's too soon to tell since polling data at this stage of the campaign is not reliably predictive for general election results), I'm just giving both the Republicans and Democrats an even chance of winning the White House and, therefore, having control of the Senate were we to have a 50/50 tie. But what if, in line with the current GJ consensus, you think that the the Democrats have about a 2-to-1 advantage in the general election for president, instead of the even money line I'm taking? If you imported that assumption into my little model, then the Republicans still have a 0.54 (=0.44 + 0.10) probability of keeping control of the Senate, while Democrats have a 0.46 (=0.26 + 0.20) probability of doing so.  -- [a] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/186530

I agree with @Jean-Pierre and others that it's too soon to determine, with much precision, probabilities for this question. That said, we're getting there. Since this is my initial forecast, I'll just try to develop a reasonable prior. Here are the basic facts (which you can skip if you're already in-the-know): There are 34 seats are up for re-election. 24 are currently held by Republicans, and 10 are held by Democrats. Since there are 54 Republicans in the Senate now, that means that the Republicans can count on a bare minimum of 30 seats after the election, and the Democrats can count on a bare minimum of 36 seats. (I'm counting the 2 independents who caucus with the Democrats as Democrats for now, but I'll revisit this point later.)  17 of the seats up for election are functionally out of play. 10 of these are held by Republicans, so they can really count on 40 seats after the election. The other 7 are held by Democrats, so their floor is really 43 seats. Of the 17 seats that are competitive to one degree or another, 14 of these competitive seats are currently held by Republicans and 3 are held by Democrats. So much for the basic facts. It would be nice to have some sense of how likely it is that a Democrat or a Republican will win each of these 17 competitive elections.  And Wikipedia (of all places!) provides some raw useful information to this end[a]. (You can see this table here: https://pythagorassite.wordpress.com/2016/03/24/which-party-will-control-the-us-senate-after-the-november-2016-election/) The final four columns of this table list estimates of how likely each of these Senatorial seats is to go to either a Republican or a Democrat. The estimates come from the Cook Report, the University of Virginia Center for Politics, Roll Call, and the Daily Kos. Since these are qualitative assessments, and we need quantitative assessments, I (somewhat arbitrarily) came up with the following cypher: Safe D = 0.90 probability of D victory
Likely D = 0.75 probability of D victory
Lean D/Tilt D = 0.60 probability of D victory
Tossup = just what it sounds like, 0.50 probability of D victory And, of course, I did the same for Republicans. I'm certainly open to better translation of the qualitative assessments into quantitative assessments, but this seems like a reasonable place to start. My next step was to average the four quantitative assessments. While I didn't weight any of the sources of these assessments, I was tempted to give the Cook Report added weight because of its reputation for accuracy[b]. Again, I'm open to better approaches. Next, I determined the mean, median, and standard deviation of the average assessments. (You can see this table here: https://pythagorassite.wordpress.com/2016/03/24/which-party-will-control-the-us-senate-after-the-november-2016-election/) Hence, for any given competitive Senate seat, the expected value to the Republicans is 0.61, and the expected value to the Democrats is 0.39. And the most likely outcome is that Republican end up with 50.5 Senate seats, while Democrats get 49.5. Of course, there's a small problem here - namely, that actual Senate seats come in discrete quantities along the lines of the positive integers. No one is going to end up with 0.583774 of a Senate seat any time soon! But the magic of numbers[c] comes to the rescue again. We know that in order to retain their majority in the Senate, Republicans will need to win 11 of the 17 seats up for grabs in these competitive races, since they have a floor of 40 seats. And 11/17 = 0.65, rounding up a bit. Furthermore, we know that the standard deviation for the data series I mentioned is 0.20[d], which you can take my word for if you don't want to do your own calculation. Given this data, there's a 0.4207 (call it 0.42) probability that the Republicans will retain 51 or more Senate seats in this election cycle. Contrariwise, Democrats need 8 of the 17 Senate seats, since they have a floor of 43 seats. And 8/17 is about 0.47. Given all of the data we have, we can estimate a 0.242 probability of that happening.  But here's the thing. Eagle-eyed readers will surely have noted that 0.4207 (the probability of Republicans retaining control of the Senate) + 0.242 (the probability of the Democrats seizing control of the Senate) does not equal 1. That's because there's a rather remarkable 0.3373 probability that we'll see 50 Republicans and 50 Democrats in the Senate, according to the (admittedly overly) simple model I've pieced together! That's a big surprise to me. Here are 2 take aways from this fact: To start with, GJ needs to step up and tell us how they mean to score this event if there's a 50/50 split in the Senate. For practical purposes, of course, control will rest in the hands of the party that has the tie-breaking vote, and that will be whichever party wins the presidential election. If that's what GJ has in mind, I hope they'll say so soon (and I apologize if they've already done so, but I've missed it). Furthermore, if the importance of the presidential election didn't seem clear enough to me before, it certainly does now. The outcome of the presidential election has a more than 1-in-3 chance of determining which party has control of the Senate. That's huge. The upshot for the time being: I'm going to assign each party half of the value of 0.3373, but that's just a temporary fix.  Four more points need to be made: First, the two independents in the Senate are Angus King (ME) and Bernie Sanders (VT). Both Sen. King and Sen. Sanders caucus as Democrats. Hell, Sen. Sanders is running to be the Democratic nominee for president in 2016. So it's pretty safe to think of them as Democrats, though it would be very nice to have confirmation from the GJ judges on this point. By the way, neither Sen. King nor Sen. Sanders is up for reelection this year, as they are both Class 1 Senators.  Second, I haven't tried to use any historical data to help guide my forecasting, and that worries me. I believe that there's a rough-and-ready tendency for the party who has a two-term president completing his time in office to lose Senate seats[e]. But I need to do more homework on this before I try to upgrade my little toy of a model. Third, I've treated the Senate elections as if they were independent variables. That's something of a fiction. Senate elections are likely to be deeply influenced by the presidential election, and there's long been speculation that a Trump candidacy could be a disaster for Republicans in Congress[f]. But this election cycle has been pretty damn hard to predict. (The good news: It's not *boring*. The bad news: It's *not* boring.) So I'm going to put a pin in this until there's enough solid empirical data to use. (And, for Pete's sake, please tell me if there is, and I'm not in the loop.) Fourth and finally, all of this bean counting gets scrambled if a Senator dies or has to leave office. "The U.S. Constitution grants the state legislatures the power to determine how U.S. Senators are to be replaced, including empowering the chief executive (the governor) do make these appointments"[g]. Since Republican governors outnumber Democratic governors more than 3-to-2[h], and Republicans control a little more than twice as many State legislatures as Democrats[i]. So Republicans have a huge advantage - an advantage I don't yet have a way of incorporating into my forecast. -- [a] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Senate_elections,_2016 [b] http://www.acsu.buffalo.edu/~jcampbel/documents/CookAccuracySummary.pdf [c] http://jwilson.coe.uga.edu/EMAT6680Fa06/Hobgood/Pythagoras.html [d] Our old friend Andrey Kolmogorov reminds us that all probability values fall between 0 and 1, inclusive[c]. So we need to be a bit careful about using the standard deviation here. If we has a perfectly normal distribution, then 0.025 of the data would sit north of 1.0, while about 0.0011 would be south of 0. I'll just fix that on the fly. [e] http://www.senate.gov/history/partydiv.htm [f] For example, http://www.rollcall.com/news/how-donald-trump-could-swing-the-senate-opinion/ [g] http://uspolitics.about.com/od/thecongress/a/senate_vacancy.htm [h] http://www.politico.com/story/2015/11/republican-governors-association-winning-streak-216000 [i] https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2015/03/04/the-remarkable-republican-takeover-of-state-legislatures-in-1-chart/

It's early to make a confident forecast, with the Presidential candidates not yet determined. However, one can attempt a generic prediction along the following lines.

1. 34 Senate seats will be contested, 24 of them Republican.
2. These seats were last contested in 2010, a great year for the Republicans who used the newly introduced "Obamacare" to good effect. 
3. 2010 was a mid-term year whereas this time turnout turnout is expected to be higher and this usually helps the Democrats. Also, I don't see any issue as emotive as Obamacare this time,. 
4. It looks like the economy will continue to grow, though probably at a slower rate, and though there is a possibility of foreign policy setbacks (Iran, Syria etc) it is more likely there won't be.
5.Contrasted to the Republican candidates, the Democrats appear in much better shape, and Obama's own popularity graph seems to be rising above his earlier lows.
6. If the Republicans lose 5 seats out of their 24, they'll end up with 49 and without a majority. With the conditions listed above helping the Democrats, a loss of 5 seats seems more likely than not.
7. Getting into specifics, how many of the Republican seats are in states that Obama carried in 2012? Florida, Wisconsin, Illinois, New Hampshire, Ohio and Pennsylvania - of course some of the incumbents will be popular enough to overcome the trend, but I think that's enough to sway my initial forecast towards the Democrats.
8. If Trump is the Republican candidate, the swing away from his party may be greater. There are still about eight months left, plenty of time to adjust in either direction.

It's a little too early to make an accurate probability estimate as the primary season hasn't concluded yet. Once the candidates have been decided, I might feel that I need to revise my forecast substantially. Current composition of the US Senate: Republicans 54, Democrats 44, Independents 2 (both caucus with Democrats). 2016 should be a Democratic year for the simple reason that more vulnerable Republican seats are in play this year. My relatively high forecast is based on four assumptions:
1. Donald Trump is the Republican nominee, which likely means that there will be at least a modest wave (or down-ballot effect) that favors the Democrats.
2. Hillary Clinton wins the election, which means her vice-president casts the tie-breaking vote if there is a 50/50 split in the Senate.
3. Democrats win all 5 toss-up races (4 Rs, 1 D). These are Nevada, Florida, Illinois, New Hampshire, and Wisconsin.
4. Joe Sestak beats Pat Toomey in Pennsylvania.
5. Ted Strickland beats Rob Portman in Ohio. Democrats could also pick up North Carolina, but I am betting against that for now. If 2016 turns out to be a big wave election, even more Republican seats could come into play. Conversely, a couple of black swan or grey swan events (e.g., a recession) could turn 2016 into a Republican year. I'm currently forecasting that the Democrats will pick up 6-seats, which gives them a 2-seat cushion if Clinton wins the presidency and a 1-seat cushion if Trump wins. I have relied on the expertise of political handicappers Charlie Cook, Stu Rothenberg, and Larry Sabato for a long time. They're very good political analysts, although their track record as forecasters is somewhat mixed. Michael Barone's _Almanac of American Politics_ is the best reference guide to Congressional districts. Charlie Cook: http://cookpolitical.com/senate/charts/race-ratings
Stu Rothenberg: http://rothenberggonzales.com/ratings/senate
Larry Sabato: http://www.centerforpolitics.org/crystalball/2016-senate/
Michael Barone: http://www.amazon.com/The-Almanac-American-Politics-2016/dp/1938518292 I do have a couple of questions about how this question will be resolved. I'm assuming that the Independents who caucus with Democrats count as Democrats and Independents who caucus with Republicans count as Republicans. I'm also assuming that, in case of a 50/50 tie, the party that has the vice-presidency will count as having the majority in the Senate. I'll ask for clarification just to be sure.
Haven't run numbers on this yet; this is off the top of my head.
